## Historical Context of the Bourbon Restoration (1814-1830)

Le Rouge et le Noir is set in the latter years of the Bourbon Restoration (1814–1830) and the days of the 1830 July Revolution that established the Kingdom of the French (1830–1848).(no content)The Bourbon monarchy was restored after Napoleon's defeat in 1814, marking a period of conservative restoration following the revolutionary and Napoleonic upheavals.

## Social Hierarchy and Class System

The Restoration period was characterized by significant social tensions between different classes:

### The Aristocracy vs. Rising Bourgeoisie
The fading aristocracy or conservatives tried to reintroduce absolutism and consolidate political power in the Catholic Church and the Army. But a rising middle class with commercial and industrial interests had become a dominant social force throughout France.(no content)Stendhal vividly portrays the cultural and historical context of the time, capturing the tensions between the old aristocracy and the rising bourgeoisie. The novel explores the tensions between the old aristocracy and the emerging bourgeoisie, reflecting the societal changes occurring in France at the time.

### Social Mobility Challenges
Accordingly, early in the story, Julien Sorel observes that under the Bourbon Restoration it is impossible for a man of his plebeian class to distinguish himself in the (red-uniformed) army (as he might have done under Napoleon), hence only a (black-uniformed) church career offers social advancement and glory.(no content)He laments the fact that he was born too late to take part in what he sees as the heroism of Napoleon's age and the ease of social mobility via the Napoleonic military. In the post-war Bourbon restoration, Julien believes that the church hierarchy is the means for him to ascend.

## Religion's Role

The Catholic church had been rehabilitated after the revolution and gained back its leading role in the state and largely so in society. The Church became a primary avenue for social advancement for those of lower birth, as military careers were no longer viable paths to distinction.

## Education and Social Commentary

Stendhal provides insights into the power dynamics, class divisions, and political intrigues of the era. Stendhal critiques the hypocrisy and constraints of the aristocratic society, highlighting the challenges faced by those striving for social mobility.

## Stendhal's "The Red and the Black" as Social Mirror

The book portrays post-reformation France in a lively, intelligent and daring fashion; its intention is to expose the hypocrisy of society. From its onset, Stendhal considered The Red and the Black a 'mirror of France in 1830' – an interesting enterprise, even if not rare in the literary scene.

### Contemporary Relevance
The Red and the Black, a French novel written by Stendhal and published in 1830, is a social and psychological novel, investigating the socioeconomic structure of France and the psychology of its main characters separately and in interaction.(no content)Stendhal writes fiercely of his contemporary world, the post-Napoleonic reign of the reactionary Charles X. Stendhal lived in Paris from November 1821 to November 1830, and his novel is based on first-hand experience of the corruption, hypocrisy and self-interest that prevailed.

The novel captures the political tensions leading up to the July Revolution of 1830, depicting a society where hypocrites, but more remains to be revealed. Stendal portrays the people of France as those whose proud souls are a dangerous medley of hypocrisy and self-deceit, and who are consequently lost in confusion.
